title: Ageing, Health and Society
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: The aim of this course is to provide students with a basic understanding of population ageing from the sociological perspectives. It focuses on the development of a multi-dimensional understanding of the factors that affect the health of older adults and the ways that socio-demographic changes shape societal attitudes towards old age. Emphasis is placed on discussions of the impact of population ageing on the social and health care needs of a society.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  1. Analyze the global trends of population ageing and their impact on health care, social and economic issues in society. 2. Develop theoretical understandings in the societal changes in ageing. 3. Justify the social construction of "age" and "ageing process" in individual and social contexts. 4. Synthesize the impact of population ageing on health and social care needs in society.

academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: This course aims to equip students with foundational knowledge and essential skills to address the basic care needs of older people. Emphasis is placed on promoting an understanding of the basic principles of care to help older people to meet their basic life needs. Fundamental concepts such as nutrition, exercise, oral care, basic hygiene care, communication, and psychosocial care are also covered.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  1. Explain the purposes and content of various geriatric assessment tools. 2. Demonstrate the ability to conduct comprehensive assessments to determine the biopsychosocial needs and conditions of older people and their families. 3. Deliver client education for older people and their families.             4. Describe the principles and demonstrate the ability to perform basic skills for providing care to older people safely and effectively. 5. Discuss the special issues relating to the provision of basic care to older people. The issues include infection control, occupational safety, and inter-professional practice.
syllabus: 1.       Course Introduction 2.       Basic anatomy & physiology3.       Nutrition and hydration4.       Frailty in older adults5.       Skincare for older adults Pressure injuries6.       Basic infection control with laboratory session7.       Basic health assessment with laboratory session8.       Comprehensive Geriatric Assessment (CGA)9.       Occupational safety10.      Mobility and client transfer with laboratory session11.      Safety and fall prevention12.      Fall prevention with experiential learning13.      Personal hygiene and elimination with experiential learning14.      Emergency care for older adults with laboratory session15.      Assisting with fluid and nutritional needs16.      Sleep hygiene

title: Promoting Successful Ageing: Individual and Societal Perspectives
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: The aim of this course is to provide students with a comprehensive overview of the concepts, principles and theories of successful ageing from the health and social perspectives. Emphasis is placed on exploring and discussing the subjective and objective dimensions of successful ageing, the modifiable factors affecting the achievement of successful ageing, and the strategies to promote successful ageing at both individual and societal levels.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  1. Describe the different terminologies and definitions of successful ageing. 2. Discuss how successful ageing is related to the adaptation of changes in later life from theoretical and lay perspective. 3. Discuss the strategies to promote successful ageing at individual, family and societal levels. 4. Discuss the concepts and strategies to build an age-friendly community.

title: Psychology in Ageing: Theories and Application
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: The aim of this course is to provide students with a basic understanding of the concepts and theoretical approaches of psychology relevant to ageing and aged care in various care settings. Emphasis is placed on the application of these concepts to understand individual and group behaviour and the health and social care needs of individuals and groups.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  1.        Discuss the psychological changes throughout the lifespan. 2. Examine influences of motivation, emotion, learning, memory and personality on individual and group behaviour of older people in various   health and social care settings. 3. Develop sensitivity over approaches and demonstrate effective communication skills of enhancing psychological well-being in older people4. Discuss the common major life events and challenges among older people and integrate psychological theories to explain the impact on psychological well-being.

components:

academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: This course aims to enhance the understanding of the complexities of care for people with chronic diseases. An interdisciplinary approach for the chronic disease management from health and social perspectives will be applied. It also focuses on the design of care which directly addresses the physical and psychosocial consequences of chronic diseases, especially for older people and their caregivers. Basic principles and concepts of community-based care and rehabilitation, and the importance of empowerment of patients as well as families in self-management of chronic illnesses in a community setting will be covered.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  1. Summarize the physical and psychosocial impacts of chronic diseases especially on older people  2. Identify the roles of different healthcare disciplines in managing major chronic diseases 3. Explain the concepts of multiple morbidity and comorbidity and their implications for long-term care                             4. Discuss the self-care models for chronic disease management and strategies to empower people managing their diseases  5. Discuss the types and roles of community resources in supporting people living with chronic conditions.  6. Describe the role of public health or community health practitioners in disease management
syllabus: 1.       Course Introduction2.       Hypertension, blood lipid disorders and diabetes mellitus3.       Heart disease 4.       Stroke5.       Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)6.       Musculoskeletal health7.         Pain8.       Chronic care model Community-based rehabilitation Development of a person-centered care plan9.       Renal and urinary disorders10.      Visual impairment11.      Hearing impairment12.      Medication management for older people with chronic diseases Drug safety and polypharmacy13.       Malignant neoplasms14.      Mental health and common mental health problems in older adults

title: Dementia: Prevention and Management
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: This course aims to provide students with a comprehensive overview of the pathophysiological, behavioural and psychosocial aspects of dementia. Emphasis is placed on equipping students with the knowledge and skills required to prevent, detect and manage dementia in older people. The course also highlights the roles of family caregivers, multidisciplinary care teams, and community care services in managing dementia.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  1. Describe the pathogenesis, risk factors, types, and stages of dementia.             2. Describe the comprehensive health and social assessment for dementia.  3. Discuss the physical, cognitive, behavioural and psychosocial manifestations of dementia.  4. Describe the pharmacological and non-pharmacological interventions for dementia.         5. Discuss the evidence-based care in managing dementia in the community, rehabilitative and long-term care settings.  6. Discuss the interventions to maintain and promote brain health.  7. Discuss the role of an interprofessional team approach in the care of older people with dementia and their caregivers and families.  8. Discuss the role of informal caregivers in the care of older people with dementia.  9. Discuss the role of health and social care services in the care of older people with dementia.
syllabus: Course Introduction An overview of dementia Manifestations of dementia Assessment of dementia Communication with dementia clients  Management of dementia Sociological understanding of dementia COVID-19 and dementia  Living with dementia Dementia-friendly environment  Care of informal caregivers Prevention of dementia
required_readings: Agronin, M. E. (2014). Alzheimer's disease and other dementias: A practical guide (3rd ed.). Routledge
recommended_readings: Ames, D., O’Brien, J. T., & Burns, A. (2017). Dementia (5th ed.) Chapman and Hall/CRC Press.De Waal, H. (2013). Designing and delivering dementia services. Wiley-Blackwell.

title: Ethical and Financial Issues in Ageing
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: The aim of this course is to enhance students' understanding of the ethical issues relating to aged care. It focuses on the basic ethical principles and theories relating to gerontological practice; the ethical issues and dilemmas encountered in practice; the financial planning for older people; and the funding models for aged care services.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  1. Demonstrate an understanding of the fundamental concepts in ethics and financial issues in relation to the care and services for older people.  2. Discuss the strengths and weaknesses of different approaches for ethical decision-making in ageing.  3. Enhance knowledge in resolving issues within the policy and cultural arenas, while exploring how individual personal values may sometimes conflict with professional and societal values.

academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: The aim of this course is to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of the principles, concepts and skills involved in planning and delivering aged care services in a variety of aged care settings, including community, rehabilitative and residential care settings locally and globally. The basic concepts covered include ageing in place, social involvement and participation, integrated community-based care, the home care delivery model, discharge planning, innovative practice, interdisciplinary and cross-sectoral service coordination, and the residential care home accreditation system. The course highlights the notion of health and social care partnership, and a multi-dimensional perspective is adopted to facilitate students’ examination on the service planning and delivery model for the provision of community, rehabilitative and residential care services to older people.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  1. Demonstrate an understanding of the principles, philosophies, and concepts of community, rehabilitative, and residential aged care and their relevance to older persons in a society locally and globally. 2. Demonstrate an understanding of the roles and functions of different health care and social welfare organizations in the provision of different levels of aged care services. 3. Discuss the knowledge and skills in coordinating multi-disciplinary and inter-sectoral aged care in community, rehabilitative and residential care settings 4. Describe innovative strategies to monitor quality and promote excellence in the provision of aged care services in community, rehabilitative and residential care settings.

title: Gerontological Practicum
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: The aim of this clinical practicum is to provide students with clinical practice opportunities to apply related principles, concepts and theories for planning and delivering aged care services in community, rehabilitative and residential care settings. Students are facilitated to develop their knowledge of and skills in service planning, coordination and delivery in these settings.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  1. Discuss the models for planning and delivering aged care services in community, rehabilitative and residential care settings. 2. Effectively communicate with older clients, their families, and health and social care team members in community, rehabilitative and residential care settings. 3. Apply the knowledge and skills of health and social sciences in ageing to identify the needs of older people and deliver high quality aged care services in community, rehabilitative and residential care settings. 4. Demonstrate an understanding of the principles and skills in coordinating multi-disciplinary care and optimizing inter-sectoral collaboration for the delivery of aged care services in community, rehabilitative and residential care settings. 5. Apply legal and ethical principles in delivering high quality aged care in community, rehabilitative and residential care settings.
syllabus: This clinical course facilitates development and application of knowledge and skills of health and social aged care in community, rehabilitative and residential care settings. Students are expected to discuss the service planning and delivery models adopted in these aged care settings, to demonstrate effective communication skills, to develop knowledge and skills for assessing health and social care needs, coordinating multi- disciplinary care and optimizing inter-sectoral collaboration in the delivery of aged care services, and to discuss legal and ethical issues in community aged care services.

title: Health and Social Care Policy in Ageing
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: The aim of this course is to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of policy issues relating to health and social care needs of older people. The course also examines the operation of health care and social care systems to further students' understanding of the planning and delivery of aged care services for older people.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:   Illustrate the social, political and economic issues and changes resulting from the ageing of society.   Describe the historical and cultural basis to the development of policy and welfare systems on ageing.   Critically discuss the strengths and limitations of the current policy on the delivery of aged care services in Hong Kong.  Analyze the roles, trends and ethical issues of health and social care professionals in the development and implementation of policy in ageing.
syllabus: Introduction to health and social care policy in ageing Theoretical approaches to the development of policies I - New Right and Neoliberalism Theoretical approaches to the development of policies II – Postmodernism Poverty and Social Security in ageing I Poverty and Social Security in ageing II Healthcare infrastructure for older people I Healthcare infrastructure for older people II Older people as a stakeholder -  frontline experience sharing  Life-long learning and productive ageing  Long-term care in the context of population ageing Housing policies in ageing The Dynamics of Aging in Our Future
